page.title: 11INTRODUCTION TO WOOLACOMBE
page.content: Although strictly out of this area, the village of Woolacombe is very much part of the life of Mortehoe. Descending Chapel Hill, the wide expanse of sandy beach stretches for three miles. The village itself nestles around the headland at the northern end of the beach. In 1922 Woolacombe obtained recognition as a separate village. Before that it was little more than isolated farmland, with scattered farms. In the Domesday Book it is referred to as Wolnecoma, meaning Wolves' Valley. Today the National Trust owns most of the area, the gift of Miss Chichester of Arlington Court,so that development is restricted to retain the open nature of the dunes behind the beach, and the towering hills around the village.
